title: Meghan and Harry ‘plan six week break’ after emotionally opening up on struggles
text:
The Duke and Duchess of Sussex give fans a behind the scene look at their southern Africa tour in an hour-long documentary tonight (Picture: ITV)

Prince Harry and Meghan Markle are expected to take a six week break from Royal duties over the Christmas period for ‘much-needed family time’.

It comes after Meghan opened up about the emotional struggle she has felt being in the spotlight over the past year for a new ITV documentary which airs tonight.

She told presenter Tom Bradby during her 10-day tour of southern Africa alongside Harry that becoming a mother while living under the glare of the media spotlight was ‘a very real thing to be going through behind the scenes’.

Meghan even thanked the presenter for asking how she is coping, saying: ‘Not many people have asked if I’m OK.’

Speaking ahead of the programme, Mr Bradby, a friend of Harry, said he believed the couple are ‘vulnerable and bruised’.

As their Africa tour ended, the Duke and Duchess of Sussex both brought separate legal actions against parts of the press.

Meghan is suing the Mail on Sunday for breach of privacy after it published a private letter between her and her estranged father.

Harry later filed his own proceedings at the High Court in relation to the alleged illegal interception of voicemail messages by journalists from the Sun, News of the World and Daily Mirror.

After a clip of her emotional interview was published on Friday, the Duchess received an outpouring of support online, with #WeLoveYouMeghan trending in less than an hour.

According to a Royal source, the couple have a full schedule of engagements and commitments until mid-November.

After this point ‘they will be taking some much-needed family time’ the source told the Sunday Times.

Harry and Meghan introduce Archie to Archbishop Desmond Tutu during a visit to the Desmond & Leah Tutu Legacy Foundation in Cape Town (Picture: Rex)

The couple are looking forward to their first Christmas with Archie, who was born in May, and are expected to join the Queen and other members of the Royal Family at Sandringham in Norfolk.

It is understood they will fly to Los Angeles next month to spend Thanksgiving with Meghan’s mother, Doria Ragland.

The one-hour ITV documentary gives fans a behind the scenes look at Harry and Meghan’s trip to southern Africa including some of the causes they most care about.

In a new clip from the programme, released today, the Duke of Sussex says Cape Town in South Africa would be an ‘amazing’ place for his family to live.

But, he adds, it could be challenging to find a way to ‘make as much difference’ as he would want.

Harry said he and Meghan will spend ‘the rest of our lives’ working in conservation across Africa.

Harry told the documentary: ‘I don’t know where we could live in Africa at the moment.

‘We have just come from Cape Town – that would be an amazing place to be able to base ourselves, of course it would, but with all the problems that are going on there, I just don’t see how we would be able to really make as much difference as we want to without the issues and the judgment of how we would be with those surroundings.

Advertisement

‘I think it is a very hard place to live when you know what is going on and then you are again slightly disconnected from it.’

During the tour, Meghan and Archie stayed in South Africa, while Harry visited Malawi, Botswana and Angola, where he highlighted the anti-landmine work of his mother, Diana, Princess of Wales.

Harry & Meghan: An African Journey is on ITV tonight at 9pm.
